title: Żędowice
text:
Żędowice () is a <a href="village">village</a> in the administrative district of <a href="Gmina%20Zawadzkie">Gmina Zawadzkie</a>, within <a href="Strzelce%20County">Strzelce County</a>, <a href="Opole%20Voivodeship">Opole Voivodeship</a>, in southern Poland. It lies approximately south of <a href="Zawadzkie">Zawadzkie</a>, north-east of <a href="Strzelce%20Opolskie">Strzelce Opolskie</a>, and east of the regional capital <a href="Opole">Opole</a>.
The village has a population of 2,500.
History.
In the 10th century the area became part of the emerging <a href="Duchy%20of%20Poland%20%28c.%20960%E2%80%931025%29">Polish state</a>, and later on, it was part of Poland, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bohemia">Bohemia (Czechia)</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Prussia</a>, and <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the Germans operated the E575 <a href="Forced%20labour%20under%20German%20rule%20during%20World%20War%20II">forced labour</a> subcamp of the <a href="Stalag%20VIII-B">Stalag VIII-B/344</a> <a href="German%20prisoner-of-war%20camps%20in%20World%20War%20II">prisoner-of-war camp</a> in the village. After Germany's defeat in the war, in 1945, the village became again part of Poland.
Transport.
There is a train station in Żędowice, and the <a href="Voivodeship%20road">Voivodeship road</a> 901 passes through the village.
References.
